journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine

title-group.article-title: Contribution of posterolateral corner structures to knee joint translational and rotational stabilities: A computational study

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, Kyung Hee University, Yongin, Korea
2Department of Applied Mathematics, Kyung Hee University, Yongin, Korea
3Department of Orthopedic Surgery, KonKuk University Medical Center, KonKuk University School of Medicine Seoul, Korea

author-notes.corresp: Yoon Hyuk Kim, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Kyung Hee University, Yongin-si, Gyeonggi-do 446-701, Korea. Email: yoonhkim@khu.ac.kr

abstract.p: It has been reported that posterolateral corner structures, including the lateral collateral ligament, the popliteus tendon, and the popliteofibular ligament, may play important roles in reducing external rotational and posterior translational instabilities. However, there are few studies focusing on the quantitative influence of posterolateral corner structures on knee joint stability, due to the difficulty of controlling experimental conditions. In this study, a knee model that included posterolateral corner structures was developed. It was validated by comparison to previous experimental studies using the posterior drawer test, dial test, and varus stress test. The posterior translation, external rotation, and varus rotation were then predicted in order to investigate the contribution of posterolateral corner structures to translational and rotational stabilities. Our results indicate that posterolateral corner structures, including the popliteofibular ligament and the popliteus tendon, could contribute to posterior translational and external rotational stabilities, as clinical observations had suggested. Therefore, the addition of posterolateral corner structures to knee joint models may improve the utility of such models.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
An understanding of knee joint biomechanics, such as bone kinematics, joint stability, ligament forces and stress, and contact pressures between knee joint components, is essential for the protection, diagnosis, surgery, and rehabilitation of knee joint injuries. Computational modeling technologies have been used to predict the kinematics and kinetics of the knee joint due to challenge of evaluating in vivo movement and the corresponding forces, pressures, and stresses on bones and soft tissues. 1
–8 Quasi-static knee joint models, including bones, ligaments, and cartilage, were developed first, 1,3 and then dynamic knee models were developed. 2,5 In these previous studies, ligaments were used as knee joint stabilizers. Four major ligaments, which are the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL), posterior cruciate ligament (PCL), medial collateral ligament (MCL), and lateral collateral ligament (LCL), were conventionally included in the models. In addition, the medial, lateral, oblique politeal, and arcuate popliteal bundles of the posterior knee capsules were simulated in a recent study. 4,7

It has been reported that the posterolateral corner (PLC) structures, including the LCL, popliteus tendon (PLT), and popliteofibular ligament (PFL), may play important roles in reducing the external rotational and posterior translational instabilities, because injuries of the PLC, commonly caused by athletic traumas, motor vehicle accidents, and falls, result in the translational or rotational instability of the knee joint. 9
–13 There were also several cadaveric experimental studies that were performed to investigate the role of the PLC structures. 14–16 The contribution of PFL to posterolateral (PL) stability was analyzed, and the functional role of the PLC structures in providing knee joint stability was investigated. However, to our knowledge, there are few studies to assess contribution of the PLC structures to joint stabilities with computational knee joint models. In this study, a three-dimensional knee joint model, which included the PLC structures (LCL, PLT, and PFL), was developed, and the model was validated by comparing to previous experimental studies of the posterior drawer test, the dial test, and the varus stress test. The contribution of PLC structures to the knee joint translational and rotational stabilities was then quantitatively investigated.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Three-dimensional models of the femur, tibia, and fibula were constructed based on computed tomography (CT) images of 26-year-old male subject. Solid shell models of the cartilage layer and meniscus between the femur and the tibia were also reconstructed. Commercial software such as 3D-Doctor (Able Software Co., USA), Rapidform 2004 (INUS Technology Inc., USA), and SolidWorks (SolidWorks Inc., USA) were used for the modeling process. The developed models were imported into the dynamic analysis software, RecurDyn version 7 (Function Bay Inc., Korea) (Figure 1).

caption.p: Model of the knee joint: (a) anterior view, (b) posterior view, (c) medial view, and (d) lateral view.
ACL: anterior cruciate ligament; PCL: posterior cruciate ligament; MCL: medial collateral ligament; LCL: lateral collateral ligament; PLT: popliteus tendon; PFL: popliteofibular ligament.

sec.p: The viscoelastic contact between the femoral and tibial cartilages was estimated based on the elastic contact stiffness (500 N/mm) and damping coefficient (5 N s/mm) given in previous studies. 17–19 The contact between the meniscus and these cartilages was also defined using the parameters (20 N/mm of elastic stiffness and 5 N s/mm of damping coefficient) obtained from discrete element analysis technique. 20 The material properties of the cartilage and meniscus, such as Young’s modulus and Poisson ratio, were obtained from the literature. 19,20

Lateral and medial meniscuses were attached to the tibial plateau by horn attachments, which can constrain meniscus motions. Each horn was modeled as two linear springs. In addition, the transverse ligaments were also included as spring–damper systems. The anatomical and material properties of the horn attachments and transverse ligaments such as attachment points, stiffness, and damping coefficients were available in the literature. 19

The four major ligaments, ACL, PCL, MCL, and LCL, were included in the knee joint model (Figure 1). The ACL and PCL were modeled with two bundles, while the MCL and LCL were modeled with three bundles. 3,5 Two bundles of deep capsular fibers in the MCL (aCM and pCM) were included. 6 The medial, lateral, oblique popliteal, and arcuate popliteal bundles of the posterior knee capsule (CAPm, CAPl, CAPo, and CAPa) were also developed. 7 Finally, the PLT and PFL within PLC structures were modeled (Figure 1). 21–23 The origins and insertions of ligament bundles were decided, and each ligament bundle was modeled as a nonlinear spring with a damper based on previous studies. 3,24,25 The popliteus muscle force was included in the model. The force of 44 N was derived based on the cross-sectional area of the popliteus muscle and maximum muscle power. 26

The models with 30°, 60°, and 90° of flexion were obtained by rotating the tibia with the soft tissue attached since the model was initially developed at extension, which supposed to be 0° of flexion. The tibia was flexed with 1° of increment with respect to its mechanical axis when the femur was fixed by minimizing the total potential energy and satisfying the mechanical equilibrium.

To validate the knee model, three typical test methods were considered: (1) posterior drawer test, (2) dial test, and (3) varus stress test. In the posterior drawer test, a posterior force was applied to the knee center, which was the midpoint of the transcondylar line. 27 In the dial and varus stress tests, an external tibial and a varus moment were applied to the tibial insertion site of the PL bundle of PCL. First, the posterior tibial translations of the intact and PCL-deficient knees in the posterior drawer test under 134 N at 0°, 30°, 60°, and 90° of flexion were compared to previous experimental studies. The models with 30°, 60°, and 90° of flexion were obtained by rotating the tibia with the soft tissue attached since the model was initially developed at extension, which supposed to be 0° of flexion. The tibia was flexed with 1° of increment with respect to its mechanical axis when the femur was fixed by minimizing the total potential energy and satisfying the mechanical equilibrium. 28 The dial test under 5 N m and varus stress test under 3 N m were performed for the sequential ligament sectioning study. 16 The sectioning sequence was the PFL, the PLT, and the LCL in this order. When the PLT was removed, the simulated popliteus muscle force became inactive. The rotational angles of the tibia at 0°, 30°, 60°, and 90° of knee flexion were compared to values from the experimental study. 16 In addition, the load responses (the ligament force/the applied moment) of the PFL, PLT, and LCL for the intact knee were compared to the previous cadaveric study. 11 Finally, the posterior drawer test under 134 N, the dial test under 5 N m, and the varus stress test under 5 N m were simulated for the developed model, which had the PLC structures, and the model in which the PFL and the PLT were removed. In order to investigate the contribution of the PLC structures to the knee joint stability, the posterior translation, external rotation, and varus rotation were compared.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
For the posterior drawer test under 134 N, the posterior tibial translations of the intact knee were 6.1, 4.4, 3.2, and 3.5 mm at 0°, 30°, 60°, and 90° of knee flexion, respectively, while those of the PCL-deficient knee were 7.4, 9.2, 12.3, and 9.4 mm at 0°, 30°, 60°, and 90° of knee flexion, respectively (Figure 2). For both intact and PCL-deficient knees, the translations were within the ranges of values from previous experimental studies (Figure 2). 27
–32

caption.p:
Posterior translation in posterior drawer test under 134 N for (a) intact and (b) PCL-deficient knees. The minimum and maximum values were obtained from previous experimental studies. 27
–32

sec.p: For the sequential ligament sectioning study, the dial test results were similar to the experimental results 16 except when all three ligaments (PFL, PLT, and LCL) were removed (Figure 3(a)). The average difference in the external rotation was 2.2° of the rotation when all three PLC ligaments were removed. The varus stress test results showed a similar trend in the varus rotation, even though the average difference between our results and the experimental results 16 was 2.1° (Figure 3(b)).

caption.p: Rotation angle in the (a) dial test and (b) varus stress test during the sequential sectioning.
PFL: popliteofibular ligament; PLT: popliteus tendon; LCL: lateral collateral ligament.
PFL was removed, then the PLT was cut, and then the LCL was sectioned.16

sec.p: The load responses of the PFL for the dial test were 0.0, 3.4, 15.6, and 19.7 N/N mm at 0°, 30°, 60°, and 90° of knee flexion, respectively. The differences from the results of a previous result 11 were 1.4 standard deviation (SD), 1.0 SD, 0.3 SD, and 1.1 SD, respectively (Figure 4(a)). The load responses of the PLT for the dial test were 0.2, 2.4, 13.4, and 18.2 N/N mm at 0°, 30°, 60°, and 90° of knee flexion, respectively, and the maximum difference, 1.6 SD, occurred at 30° of knee flexion (Figure 4(b)). Similarly, the load responses of the LCL were 12.0, 13.1, 5.8, and 0.2 N/N mm at 0°, 30°, 60°, and 90° of knee flexion, respectively, and the maximum difference, 1.0 SD, occurred at 60° of knee flexion (Figure 4(c)). In the varus stress test, the PFL and the PLT were not tensioned. The load responses of the LCL for the varus stress test were 10.4, 11.9, 14.3, and 6.8 N/N mm at 0°, 30°, 60°, and 90° of knee flexion, respectively, and the maximum differences from the experimental results were 1.3 SD at 60° of knee flexion (Figure 5).

caption.p: Load responses for the dial test. The maximum and minimum indicate the mean value ± standard deviation: 11 (a) PFL load response, (b) PLT load response, and (c) LCL load response.
PFL: popliteofibular ligament; PLT: popliteus tendon; LCL: lateral collateral ligament.
LCL load responses for the varus stress test. The maximum and minimum indicate the mean value ± the standard deviation. 11

sec.p:
All the posterior translations, external rotations, and varus rotations were increased when the PFL and the PLT were removed regardless of the degree of knee flexion, but the results were within the experimentally obtained ranges in the cases both with and without the PLC structures (Figure 6). 27
–37 The increases in translation for the posterior drawer test were 27.9%, 15.9%, 50.0%, and 60.0% at 0°, 30°, 60°, and 90° of knee flexion. Similarly, at 0°, 30°, 60°, and 90° of knee flexion, the external rotation was increased by 17.1%, 7.7%, 27.3%, and 53.2%, respectively, and the varus rotations were increased by 0.0%, 3.8%, 16.7%, and 29.0%, respectively.

caption.p:
Translations and rotations for three tests using the model with the PFL and the PLT (model with PLC), the model without them (model without PLC), and those from previous experimental studies: 27
–37 (a) posterior drawer test, (b) dial test, and (c) varus stress test.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Although the PLC structures were considered together as the PL capsule or popliteus arcuate ligament complex in the initial studies, 9,38 they were recently divided into the PFL, the PLT, and the LCL and observed separately. The roles of the PFL and PLT on stability were reported in previous in vitro studies. 12,14,15,33,39,40 In addition, anatomical information about the PLC structures, such as the origin and insertion of bundles, physiological cross-sectional area, and material properties such as Young’s modulus and Poisson ratio, which are essential for the development of a knee joint model including the PLC structures, was reported. 24,25

Because it has been noted that the LCL is the primary stabilizer among the PLC structures, 14,15 most knee joint models have included only the LCL. However, some sequential sectioning tests indicated that the PFL and the PLT also contribute to knee joint stability. In this study, a knee joint model, which included the PFL and the PLT, was developed. The model was validated by simulating the posterior drawer test, the dial test, and the varus stress test and comparing the test results to previous experimental studies. 27
–32 The contribution of the PFL and the PLT to the translational and rotational stabilities was determined by using the model, which included the PFL and the PLT, and comparing its performance to a model in which they were absent.

The posterior drawer test results indicated that the posterior translations were in agreement with those reported in previous experimental studies for both intact and the PCL-deficient knees, regardless of the knee flexion angle (Figure 2). The sequential ligament sectioning results for the dial test indicated that the average rotational difference between our result and previous study’s results 16 was 18.5% (Figure 3(a)). However, it was only 9.4% if we did not include cases in which the PFL, PLT, and LCL were absent (Figure 3(a)). Because the anatomical information and the material properties used in this study were not the same as those in the previous study, both a 9.4% and 18.5% difference may be acceptable for validation of the developed model. Moreover, the sectioning results for the varus stress test also supported the validity of the model because the varus rotation was similar to the previous study results (Figure 3(b)).

The maximum differences in load responses of the PFL, the PLT, and the LCL for the external dial test were 1.4 SD, 1.6 SD, and 1.0 SD, respectively, and the average values were 1.0 SD, 1.0 SD, and 0.9 SD, respectively 11 (Figure 4). For the varus stress test, the maximum difference in load responses of the LCL was 1.3 SD, and the average value was 0.6 SD (Figure 5). In addition, all the posterior translations in the posterior drawer test, the external rotations in the dial test, and the varus rotations in the varus stress test were fell within the ranges obtained from previous experimental studies regardless of the existence of the PFL and the PLT in the model (Figure 6). Therefore, it could be concluded that the validation of the developed model was established.

The posterior translations in the posterior drawer test, the external rotations in the dial test, and the varus rotations in the varus stress test were increased by an average of 38.4%, 26.3%, and 12.4%, respectively, when the PFL and the PLT were removed (Figure 6). These results suggest that the PFL and the PLT had greater influences on the posterior translation than on the external and varus rotations, which is in agreement with the clinical observation that both the PFL and the PLT are secondary stabilizers for posterior tibial translation whereas the PCL is the primary stabilizer. In addition, we confirmed that the PFL and the PLT also contributed to reduction of the external rotation, as clinical studies reported. 14,15

There are some limitations in this study. Only one young male subject was used to construct the model. Various subjects of different ages need to be studied to enhance the validity of the results, because results are also dependent on the geometry of the knee joint. The ligaments were simplified into only two or three bundles as nonlinear springs. Three typical virtual tests were performed to assess the translational and rotational stabilities. Since the dynamic analysis software was utilized, application of the kinematic information to the model using the motion capture technology can achieve a complex stability analysis during normal daily activities such as walking and jumping. Moreover, it is necessary to investigate the PFL and the PLT separately in future studies since the PFL and the PLT were considered together as the PLC structures in this study.

In conclusion, a knee model that included the PLC structures was developed and validated by comparisons to previous experimental studies of the posterior drawer test, the dial test, and the varus stress test. The posterior translation, the external rotation, and the varus rotation were then predicted to investigate the contributions of the PLC structures to the translational and rotational stabilities. Our results indicate that PLC structures, including the PFL and the PLT, could contribute to the posterior translational and external rotational stabilities, as the clinical observation suggested. Therefore, inclusion of the PLC structures in knee joint models might be helpful to improve the utility of the models. Moreover, the models may provide information to plan surgical options such as graft diameter or graft attachment site for the ACL reconstruction surgery because they can predict translational and rotational stabilities for several clinical tests.

fn.label: Declaration of conflicting interests
fn.p: All the authors disclose that there are no financial and personal relationships with other people who or organizations that could inappropriately influence (bias) this study.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This work is supported by the National Strategic R&D Program for Industrial Technology (10041605), funded by the Ministry of Trade, Industry and Energy (MOTIE).
